Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: GOALI: Advanced Physical Inspection of Counterfeit Integrated Circuits

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Counterfeit electronic components create risks when incorporated into critical systems and infrastructures since they are often below specification and/or of substandard quality. There are several different counterfeit types in the supply chain today: recycled, remarked, overproduced, out-of-spec/defective, cloned, forged documentation, and tampered. Most of the counterfeit components in the market today are chips that are not equipped with mechanisms to aid in detection of each counterfeit type. Thus, detection relies mostly on physical inspection and electrical testing.
In this work, the main objective is to improve the effectiveness of physical inspection tests which appears to be the most promising way of detecting all types of counterfeits. In this project, exhaustive characterization of counterfeit and authentic ICs is being performed in order to develop targeted defect taxonomies and a database of defect measurements for the research community. For the first time, counterfeit defects are quantified in order to develop algorithms that automatically classify suspect ICs as counterfeit or authentic In addition the PIs are developing novel non-destructive characterization techniques which shall reduce test time significantly.
Artifacts that will be shared include sample images and measurements of all defects found as well as aggregated information related to frequency of defects, mapping of defects to counterfeit type, etc. Since the proposed methods will be able to detect counterfeits of all types of microprocessors, application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs), field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS), and analog devices, many critical applications within automotive, military, medical, and transportation systems will benefit from this research. Finally, benefits for society include trustworthy electronics for healthcare and dependable computing platforms for intelligence, weather forecasting, financial transactions, military systems, cyber physical systems, and so forth.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
DES AUTO FOR MICRO & NANO SYST
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Counterfeit electronics are a prevailing supply chain issue that create risks when incorporated into critical systems and infrastructures since they are often below specification and/or of substandard quality. Most of the chips in the market today are not equipped with mechanisms to aid in detection of each counterfeit type. Thus, detection relies mostly on physical inspection and electrical tests. Electrical tests involve taking measurements from suspect components and comparing them to expected (authentic) measurements. Physical inspection is the most widely used approach in industry and has the potential of detecting a wide range of counterfeits. Physical tests extract defects related to the exterior, interior, and material composition and, thus, are widely extendable to many different electronic component types (analog, digital, mixed, large, small, etc.).

Physical inspection and electrical tests are challenging for a multitude of reasons. First, there is a wide spectrum of different counterfeit types in the supply chain today- recycled, remarked, overproduced, out-of-spec/defective, cloned, forged documentation, and tampered- all of which have their own unique features. Second, the equipment used for physical inspection are generic and not custom designed for detecting counterfeit parts. Thus, detection often requires multiple measurement sessions with most of the equipment, resulting in high test time and costs. Many of the physical inspections are also destructive and cannot be applied to all parts. Third, electrical tests require golden measurements, which are often unavailable. Fourth, counterfeit testing is performed without automation and decisions rest in the hands of subject matter experts (SMEs). This approach is time consuming, results in inconsistent results, and is difficult to adapt.  Fifth, counterfeit detection is done today in an ad-hoc fashion with no metrics for quantification against a set of counterfeit types, anomalies and defects. This makes it difficult to evaluate, compare, and improve the capabilities of different tests/equipment for counterfeit detection as well as provide automation and adaptation to new trends. Finally, many researchers in this domain do not have access to either counterfeit samples or the equipment needed to perform counterfeit detection.  

In this project, we have systematically dealt with the above challenge and developed a suite of approaches for counterfeit detection that improve costs, speed, destructive nature, and understanding of test effectiveness. Major outcomes include

  1. A book written by the PIs which discusses the current state-of-the-art, limitations, challenges, and future roadmap for work in counterfeit electronics detection and avoidance. This can have a significant impact on public knowledge, decision-making, and policies in this area;
  2. A counterfeit IC repository (www.counterfeit-IC.org) which is the first ever to host images and associated metadata from hundreds of counterfeit electronic components. The repository enables manufacturers, vendors, and academia to develop automated physical inspection techniques that detect counterfeits and prevent them from contaminating legitimate supply chains. The website allows test labs, researchers, and practitioners to share their own data and add it to the repository as well;
  3. Image processing and machine learning methods based on custom algorithms and neural networks that automatically extract defects such as scratches, dirty cavities, sanded surfaces, discolorations, marking displacement, etc. from packaged chips;
  4. Nondestructive methods of physical inspection, surface analysis, elemental analysis, and bond pull analysis of packaged integrated circuits (ICs) based on X-ray tomography, scanning electron microscopes (SEMs), terahertz (THz), and electron dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) of packaged chips. A major observaition from experiments demonstrated that X-ray exposure to chips of current technology nodes were largely unaffected by the radiation, making it safe to apply for supply chain protection;
  5. Nondestructive methods for reverse engineering printed circuit boards (PCBs), which can be used to detect counterfeit PCBs and Trojans hidden in PCBs. Further, legacy PCBs (i.e., those which are no longer being manufactured) can be reverse engineered to recover and improve the original design;
  6. An unclonable chipless RFID (UCR) tag that can be attached to items (chips, PCBs, pharmaceutical drugs, etc.) in order to track them at a cost of less than a penny and without direct line-of-sight. Further, an environmentally sensitive version of UCR can detect exposure of materials to damaging high temperatures during transit; and 
  7. Electrical test methods for recycled FPGA detection that are non-destructive and that exploit statistical anomalies in the entire FPGA fabric for a completely unsupervised approach (i.e., one that does not require access to known authentic measurements)

Ultimately, all the approaches that have resulted from this project will lead to automation in counterfeit detection, better monitoring of counterfeit trends, and improved reliability of the electronic component supply chain. Since they detect counterfeits of all types of microprocessors, application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs), field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS), and analog devices, many critical applications within automotive, military, medical, and transportation systems will benefit from this research. Finally, benefits for society include trustworthy electronics for healthcare and dependable computing platforms for intelligence, weather forecasting, financial transactions, military systems, cyber physical systems, and so forth.


Last Modified: 08/19/2017
Modified by: Domenic Forte

Images (1 of )
  • Counterfeit-IC.org promotes research and awareness for counterfeit electronics detection and avoidance. It contains a public repository that allows researchers, students, and practitioners to VIEW / EXPORT images, UPLOAD images, DEVELOP automated techniques, and LEARN about counterfeit electronics.
    FICS Research
    Public Domain
    Domenic Forte
    Counterfeit Integrated Circuits Repository
  • A Digilent Xilinx Spartan 3 Development Board was reverse-engineered using X-ray computation tomography followed by reconstruction, segmentation, vectorization, and PCB CAD file generation. Applications include counterfeit detection, Trojan detection, and legacy design recovery.
    FICS Research
    Copyrighted
    Domenic Forte
    Automated, Nondestructive PCB Reverse Engineering
  • Traditional bond pull tests for counterfeit detection and quality control are destructive. Our method uses X-ray computational tomography to extract 3D bond wire geometry and a finite element model is generated to execute tests virtually (nondestructively).
    FICS Research
    Copyrighted
    Domenic Forte
    Virtual (Simulated) Bond Pull Analysis
  • Chip-based RFID tags are costly and cannot be applied to all supply chain items. Our unclonable chipless RFID (UCR) tag can be printed or attached to chips, PCBs, and pharmaceuticals to uniquely identify them and track their movements in the supply chain at low cost.
    FICS Research
    Copyrighted
    Domenic Forte
    UCR Tag
  • We developed and demonstrated techniques for extracting defects related to surface markings, texture, and color on 100s of images captured from counterfeit ICs using the Leica DVM6 digital optical microscope.
    FICS Research
    Copyrighted
    Domenic Forte
    Automated Counterfeit Defect Detection
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Counterfeit electronics are a prevailing supply chain issue that create risks when incorporated into critical systems and infrastructures since they are often below specification and/or of substandard quality. Most of the chips in the market today are not equipped with mechanisms to aid in detection of each counterfeit type. Thus, detection relies mostly on physical inspection and electrical tests. Electrical tests involve taking measurements from suspect components and comparing them to expected (authentic) measurements. Physical inspection is the most widely used approach in industry and has the potential of detecting a wide range of counterfeits. Physical tests extract defects related to the exterior, interior, and material composition and, thus, are widely extendable to many different electronic component types (analog, digital, mixed, large, small, etc.). Physical inspection and electrical tests are challenging for a multitude of reasons. First, there is a wide spectrum of different counterfeit types in the supply chain today- recycled, remarked, overproduced, out-of-spec/defective, cloned, forged documentation, and tampered- all of which have their own unique features. Second, the equipment used for physical inspection are generic and not custom designed for detecting counterfeit parts. Thus, detection often requires multiple measurement sessions with most of the equipment, resulting in high test time and costs. Many of the physical inspections are also destructive and cannot be applied to all parts. Third, electrical tests require golden measurements, which are often unavailable. Fourth, counterfeit testing is performed without automation and decisions rest in the hands of subject matter experts (SMEs). This approach is time consuming, results in inconsistent results, and is difficult to adapt. Fifth, counterfeit detection is done today in an ad-hoc fashion with no metrics for quantification against a set of counterfeit types, anomalies and defects. This makes it difficult to evaluate, compare, and improve the capabilities of different tests/equipment for counterfeit detection as well as provide automation and adaptation to new trends. Finally, many researchers in this domain do not have access to either counterfeit samples or the equipment needed to perform counterfeit detection. In this project, we have systematically dealt with the above challenge and developed a suite of approaches for counterfeit detection that improve costs, speed, destructive nature, and understanding of test effectiveness. Major outcomes include A book written by the PIs which discusses the current state-of-the-art, limitations, challenges, and future roadmap for work in counterfeit electronics detection and avoidance. This can have a significant impact on public knowledge, decision-making, and policies in this area; A counterfeit IC repository (www.counterfeit-IC.org) which is the first ever to host images and associated metadata from hundreds of counterfeit electronic components. The repository enables manufacturers, vendors, and academia to develop automated physical inspection techniques that detect counterfeits and prevent them from contaminating legitimate supply chains. The website allows test labs, researchers, and practitioners to share their own data and add it to the repository as well; Image processing and machine learning methods based on custom algorithms and neural networks that automatically extract defects such as scratches, dirty cavities, sanded surfaces, discolorations, marking displacement, etc. from packaged chips; Nondestructive methods of physical inspection, surface analysis, elemental analysis, and bond pull analysis of packaged integrated circuits (ICs) based on X-ray tomography, scanning electron microscopes (SEMs), terahertz (THz), and electron dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) of packaged chips. A major observaition from experiments demonstrated that X-ray exposure to chips of current technology nodes were largely unaffected by the radiation, making it safe to apply for supply chain protection; Nondestructive methods for reverse engineering printed circuit boards (PCBs), which can be used to detect counterfeit PCBs and Trojans hidden in PCBs. Further, legacy PCBs (i.e., those which are no longer being manufactured) can be reverse engineered to recover and improve the original design; An unclonable chipless RFID (UCR) tag that can be attached to items (chips, PCBs, pharmaceutical drugs, etc.) in order to track them at a cost of less than a penny and without direct line-of-sight. Further, an environmentally sensitive version of UCR can detect exposure of materials to damaging high temperatures during transit; and Electrical test methods for recycled FPGA detection that are non-destructive and that exploit statistical anomalies in the entire FPGA fabric for a completely unsupervised approach (i.e., one that does not require access to known authentic measurements) Ultimately, all the approaches that have resulted from this project will lead to automation in counterfeit detection, better monitoring of counterfeit trends, and improved reliability of the electronic component supply chain. Since they detect counterfeits of all types of microprocessors, application-specific integrated circuits (ASICs), field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs), commercial-off-the-shelf (COTS), and analog devices, many critical applications within automotive, military, medical, and transportation systems will benefit from this research. Finally, benefits for society include trustworthy electronics for healthcare and dependable computing platforms for intelligence, weather forecasting, financial transactions, military systems, cyber physical systems, and so forth.
